published_attributes.title: Performance Improvement Plan - done
published_attributes.serialized_body:
If you as a Leader start to notice challenges such as those listed below, do not sit&wait but try to diagnose the root cause of the problem. 

Early signs of upcoming challenges:

  • Employee’s development level not progressing
  • Under-communication
  • Lower responsiveness
  • Lower productivity/underperformance
  • Questioning feedback given by others
  • Moody cooperation
  • Blaming others or circumstances mostly
  • Failing to deliver tasks perceived as ‘mundane’
  • Ignoring quality aspects

Lower productivity/underperformance
Questioning feedback given by others
Moody cooperation
Blaming others or circumstances mostly
Failing to deliver tasks perceived as ‘mundane’
Ignoring quality aspects

published_attributes.serialized_body:
STEP 0 

If you are already passed the early signs and notice your employee is underperforming arrange an extended 1o1 meeting with your team member to discuss the issue.

When talking to your team member remember: 

1. Don’t tell a bad performer they’re “a bad performer.”

You’re assigning them a highly loaded label, and this can cause the person to be defensive. Rather, describe what behaviors you’ve noticed and the gap in performance, as objectively as possible. Do this without personally tying that person’s identity into their work. Ask, “This is what I noticed. Would you agree, or did you see things differently?” Decrying, “You’re a bad performer” is essentially yelling at the person — and yelling doesn’t make something easier to hear.

2. Explore the general shape of any external issues.

Figure out which of these is true: (A) The employee knows they haven’t been productive or (B) The employee thinks their productivity has been acceptable. As a manager, your job is to figure out which of these two situations you’re in. The first (Problem A) is a problem of everyone understanding the consequences of unacceptable productivity. The second situation (Problem B) is a disagreement on understanding what an acceptable level of productivity is.

One of the ways to discern if you have Problem A or B on your hands is to simply ask: “How have you been feeling about your performance lately?” Based on this answer, you’ll know which of these problems is true for you.

1. Don’t tell a bad performer they’re “a bad performer.”

You’re assigning them a highly loaded label, and this can cause the person to be defensive. Rather, describe what behaviors you’ve noticed and the gap in performance, as objectively as possible. Do this without personally tying that person’s identity into their work. Ask, “This is what I noticed. Would you agree, or did you see things differently?” Decrying, “You’re a bad performer” is essentially yelling at the person — and yelling doesn’t make something easier to hear.
2. Explore the general shape of any external issues.

Figure out which of these is true: (A) The employee knows they haven’t been productive or (B) The employee thinks their productivity has been acceptable. As a manager, your job is to figure out which of these two situations you’re in. The first (Problem A) is a problem of everyone understanding the consequences of unacceptable productivity. The second situation (Problem B) is a disagreement on understanding what an acceptable level of productivity is.

One of the ways to discern if you have Problem A or B on your hands is to simply ask: “How have you been feeling about your performance lately?” Based on this answer, you’ll know which of these problems is true for you.

published_attributes.serialized_body:
What to do if you have Problem A: The employee knows they’re underperforming.

If the employee knows they haven’t been performing well, here’s a recommendation on how to structure the conversation:

  1. Recognize the problem: Before the meeting, ask the person to reflect on their performance: What’s going well? Not well? Get their perspective, and then offer your own.
  2. Identify the cause: Is the reason for underperformance something you did or didn’t do as a manager? (Here are some questions to ask to figure that out) - Is it situational to the task they were given? Is systemic to the work environment? Are there mitigating factors you weren’t initially aware of?
  3. Explore possible solutions: Discuss different possible routes to resolve the underlying cause of poor performance. For example, if the person works best with a greater context, you as a manager need to be providing more detail and support on the project. However, if you’ve already been doing that consistently, another potential option is for that person to get a different role/job. “Best outcome” doesn’t always mean just forcing the person to “work harder” and stay at the company. Consider fit, and what is best for you, the other person, and the team.
  4. Expectations: Explain to the person what are your expectations, and agree on the accepted level of performance. Agree on the actions both you and the employee will take.

If the employee knows they haven’t been performing well, here’s a recommendation on how to structure the conversation:
Recognize the problem: Before the meeting, ask the person to reflect on their performance: What’s going well? Not well? Get their perspective, and then offer your own.

Identify the cause: Is the reason for underperformance something you did or didn’t do as a manager? (Here are some questions to ask to figure that out) - Is it situational to the task they were given? Is systemic to the work environment? Are there mitigating factors you weren’t initially aware of?

Explore possible solutions: Discuss different possible routes to resolve the underlying cause of poor performance. For example, if the person works best with a greater context, you as a manager need to be providing more detail and support on the project. However, if you’ve already been doing that consistently, another potential option is for that person to get a different role/job. “Best outcome” doesn’t always mean just forcing the person to “work harder” and stay at the company. Consider fit, and what is best for you, the other person, and the team.
Expectations: Explain to the person what are your expectations, and agree on the accepted level of performance. Agree on the actions both you and the employee will take.

published_attributes.serialized_body:
What to do if you have Problem B: The employee doesn’t know they’re underperforming.

If an employee doesn’t believe their performance is suffering in any way, we recommended that you consider:

  • Gathering more detailed/deep feedback from colleagues, clients, and stakeholders of the person and share it with the person. 
  • Write down how you see the performance of that person - you could use the FUKO format (Fakty/Facts-Uczucia/Feelings-Konsekwencje/Consequences-Oczekiwania/Expectations) 
  • Can you articulate the expected level of performance? What precisely does this person need to do to improve?
  • Make sure the person understands what he/she is expected to do now. 
  • If the above step did not bring the required effect and you see that the undesired behavior repeats or intensifies, it’s time for a more formal step which is introducing the Performance Improvement Plan

If the above step did not bring the required effect and you see that the undesired behavior repeats or intensifies, it’s time for a more formal step which is introducing the Performance Improvement Plan

published_attributes.serialized_body:
What is PIP?

A well-designed PIP provides employees with the necessary directions for completing specific goals. It is an efficient tool for increasing worker productivity and resolving weaknesses in the workplace.

A PIP is designed to facilitate constructive discussion between a staff member and their supervisor and to clarify the exact work performance requiring improvement.

It is implemented, at the discretion of the manager, when it becomes necessary to help a staff member improve their performance.

What PIP is NOT?

PIP is not the first step to fire an employee. It might result in termination of the employment if the outcome is not satisfactory however it should never be a goal of PIP.

It is implemented, at the discretion of the manager, when it becomes necessary to help a staff member improve their performance.
What PIP is NOT?
PIP is not the first step to fire an employee. It might result in termination of the employment if the outcome is not satisfactory however it should never be a goal of PIP.

published_attributes.serialized_body:
PIP Ground Rules

  1. Never make the PIP a surprise
  2. Let the employee know a PIP is a possibility
  3. Draft the plan with the employee’s input. An effective performance improvement plan is “we can improve together” and not just “I’m telling you what to change.” Every step of the way, from having the initial discussion about poor performance to defining the weekly check-points, you should be co-creating the PIP, and working together to figure out how to get to the outcome you both want to achieve.
  4. Always consult with your HRBP and Manager before introducing PIP

blocks.text: PIP Ground Rules

Let the employee know a PIP is a possibility

Draft the plan with the employee’s input. Always consult with your HRBP and Manager before introducing PIP

published_attributes.serialized_body:
What makes PIP successful?

📆 Good timing - do not procrastinate PIP 

🗣 Understanding the reason behind underperformance 

👉 Providing specific examples of unacceptable behaviors

🎯 Create SMART goals 

📜 Clearly set up expectations and consequences when introducing PIP

blocks.text: What makes PIP successful?
📆 Good timing - do not procrastinate PIP
🗣 Understanding the reason behind underperformance
👉 Providing specific examples of unacceptable behaviors
🎯 Create SMART goals
📜 Clearly set up expectations and consequences when introducing PIP

published_attributes.serialized_body:
Steps to take when introducing PIP

  1. Open up a dialogue with the employee first (if you haven’t done it before when you noticed early signs)
  2. Find the root causes of the issues (if you haven’t done it before when you noticed early signs)
  3. Contact your HRBP who will help you draft an official PIP and prepare for the conversation with a team member.
  4. Draft the PIP template: - Note down and explain the areas that are below your expectations - Set achievable goals, consult with the employee on the exact metrics and KPIs
  5. Provide guidance and positive reinforcement
  6. Provide the necessary resources, training, and time
  7. Check it regularly (at least once a week) and update the progress or lack of it in the PIP document.
  8. If circumstances changes (i.e. project scope changes) amend the goals for PIP accordingly
  9. Review your PIP appropriately

Find the root causes of the issues (if you haven’t done it before when you noticed early signs)

Draft the PIP template:  - Note down and explain the areas that are below your expectations - Set achievable goals, consult with the employee on the exact metrics and KPIs
Provide guidance and positive reinforcement
Provide the necessary resources, training, and time
Check it regularly (at least once a week) and update the progress or lack of it in the PIP document.
If circumstances changes (i.e. project scope changes) amend the goals for PIP accordingly
Review your PIP appropriately

published_attributes.serialized_body:
What if PIP finishes with a negative result?

If you are approaching the end of PIP and suspect or know already that PIP will finish with negative results reach out to your dedicated HRBP and your leader to discuss the “hows of offboarding”. Each termination might be different, depending on the circumstances therefore it’s not possible to list all the steps to follow, but here is a very generic action plan. 

Offboarding steps:

  1. A week before the end of PIP talk to your Leader and HRBP to agree on all steps and conditions of termination. 
  2. Before the final meeting with the employee Payroll/Legal needs to draft a termination note - this might take up to a few days.
  3. You should inform the employee about the termination at the final meeting summing up PIP results- there should be a witness to this conversation (typically HRBP).
  4. If the meeting is done online, the employee needs to receive the termination via email during the meeting, and reply with an email that he/she received the termination notice and agrees to the conditions. 
  5. Once an employee accepts the conditions you need to send the confirmation of termination of employment to the Payroll team - this will trigger the contract termination and the Payroll&IT ops team will take over from here. 
  6. Post a note on Conflu informing about termination- please use ‘termination note template’ to ensure others about the fair process.

blocks.text: What if PIP finishes with a negative result?

If you are approaching the end of PIP and suspect or know already that PIP will finish with negative results reach out to your dedicated HRBP and your leader to discuss the “hows of offboarding”. Each termination might be different, depending on the circumstances therefore it’s not possible to list all the steps to follow, but here is a very generic action plan.
Offboarding steps:
A week before the end of PIP talk to your Leader and HRBP to agree on all steps and conditions of termination.
Before the final meeting with the employee Payroll/Legal needs to draft a termination note - this might take up to a few days.
You should inform the employee about the termination at the final meeting summing up PIP results- there should be a witness to this conversation (typically HRBP).

If the meeting is done online, the employee needs to receive the termination via email during the meeting, and reply with an email that he/she received the termination notice and agrees to the conditions.

Once an employee accepts the conditions you need to send the confirmation of termination of employment to the Payroll team - this will trigger the contract termination and the Payroll&IT ops team will take over from here.
Post a note on Conflu informing about termination- please use ‘termination note template’ to ensure others about the fair process.

published_attributes.serialized_body:
PIP - additional information:

  • Please inform your dedicated HRBP about both positive and negative results of the employee's Performance Improvement Plan
  • As a consequence of the improvement plan (positive result), the person should typically not be considered for Salary Review in the nearest round, unless the Manager of the team requests otherwise. In such a case, this should be discussed with the team’s HRBP.
  • PIP is confidential - please don’t share information about your team members' improvement plan with his/her colleagues or the project team.

blocks.text: PIP - additional information:
Please inform your dedicated HRBP about both positive and negative results of the employee's Performance Improvement Plan

As a consequence of the improvement plan (positive result), the person should typically not be considered for Salary Review in the nearest round, unless the Manager of the team requests otherwise. In such a case, this should be discussed with the team’s HRBP.
PIP is confidential - please don’t share information about your team members' improvement plan with his/her colleagues or the project team.
